message.content: test out the new github-docs mcp tool

content.text: I'll test out the github-docs MCP tool by exploring its capabilities.
Great! Now let me fetch some documentation and search for specific information:

# Astro Docs To all who come to this happy place: welcome. This is the repo for [docs.astro.build](https://docs.astro.build/). This repo contains all the source code we use to build our docs site. [![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/#https://github.com/withastro/docs) [![Open with CodeSandbox](https://assets.codesandbox.io/github/button-edit-lime.svg)](https://codesandbox.io/p/github/withastro/docs) [![Open in Codeflow](https://developer.stackblitz.com/img/open_in_codeflow.svg)](https://pr.new/github.com/withastro/docs) ## We are Astro Astro is an all-in-one web framework for building fast, content-focused websites. We want everyone to be successful building sites, and that means helping everyone understand how Astro works. ## You are Awesome You can also help make the docs awesome. Your feedback is welcome. Your writing, editing, translating, designing, and developing skills are welcome. You being a part of our community is welcome. ## Chat with Us You can learn more about Astro, get support, and meet other devs in [our Discord community](https://astro.build/chat). ## Raise an Issue Is something missing? Is something confusing? Is something wrong? Creating a new Issue puts a problem on our radar! [See if your issue has already been reported](https://github.com/withastro/docs/issues), and if not, [create a new one](https://github.com/withastro/docs/issues/new/choose). ## Share an Idea Could something be better? Want to share an idea with us? Discussions are threads where you can offer feedback on things that might not exactly be problems to be fixed but are ideas to be explored. [Join the Docs Discussions](https://github.com/withastro/docs/discussions) where we brainstorm, ask questions, share hopes and dreams... ## Make a Fix or Contribution Did you find a typo, a broken link, or another item with an obvious quick fix? If you can see what the problem is, and you know how to fix it, then you can make a PR (pull request) with the change and contribute to the docs repo yourself. > Want to make a larger contribution? Please see [CONTRIBUTING.md](https://github.com/withastro/docs/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md) first! ## Translate a Page Speak another language natively? Join our i18n gang on Discord or jump into the PRs to help with reviewing existing draft translations! Check out the dedicated [i18n guide](https://contribute.docs.astro.build/guides/i18n/) for more details. ### Translation progress ## Next Steps - [Read the docs](https://docs.astro.build/) - [Raise an issue](https://github.com/withastro/docs/issues/new) - [Participate in a discussion](https://github.com/withastro/docs/discussions) - [Join the #docs channel on Discord](https://discord.gg/cZDZU3hJHc)

content.text:
## github-docs MCP Tool Test Results

The tool works well! Here's what I tested:

### ‚úÖ Library Mapping (`match_common_libs_owner_repo_mapping`)
- **React**: Found `reactjs/react.dev`
- **Astro**: Found `withastro/docs`
- **Vue**: No mapping found (returns error message)

### ‚úÖ Fetch Documentation (`fetch_generic_documentation`)
Successfully fetched the README from `withastro/docs` repo.

### ‚ö†Ô∏è Search Documentation (`search_generic_documentation`)
Searched for "SSR server-side rendering with Vue components" but got no results. The tool indicates the docs may still be indexing or the query didn't match. Falls back to showing the main README.

### üîç Code Search (`search_generic_code`)
Not tested yet - this would search actual code files in repos.

### Key Capabilities:
1. **Quick library lookup** - Maps common library names to their doc repos
2. **Fetch entire documentation** - Gets README/docs from GitHub repos
3. **Semantic search** - Searches within documentation (requires indexing)
4. **Code search** - Can search through actual code files with pagination

This tool is useful for quickly pulling documentation from GitHub repos during development, especially for understanding framework-specific patterns or checking API references.

## github-docs MCP Code Search Test Results

### ‚úÖ Pagination Works
Successfully retrieved page 2 of 3 for "useState hook" query showing results 31-60 of 63 total matches.

### ‚ö†Ô∏è File Content Fetching Issue
Attempted to fetch the actual content of `useState.md` but got an error: **Response exceeds 64,000 token limit**. The file is too large to fetch directly.

### ‚úÖ Nanostores Search
Found 22 matches across Astro docs in multiple languages, including:
- `sharing-state-islands.mdx` 
- `sharing-state.mdx`
- `preact.mdx` integration guides

### Key Findings:

**Strengths:**
1. **Excellent code search** - Fast, accurate GitHub code search with scoring
2. **Pagination support** - 30 results per page with clear pagination info
3. **Multi-language results** - Finds matches across documentation translations
4. **Direct GitHub links** - Provides URLs, Git URLs, and file paths

**Limitations:**
1. **Large file content** - Cannot fetch files >64K tokens via URL fetch
2. **No content preview** - Search results don't include code snippets
3. **Documentation indexing** - Semantic search may need time to index

**Best Use Cases:**
- Finding which files contain specific code patterns
- Discovering where APIs/features are documented
- Locating example usage across a repo
- Understanding documentation structure

This tool excels at **discovery** (finding files) rather than **content retrieval** (reading large files).

1‚Üí# CLAUDE.md
     2‚Üí
     3‚ÜíThis file provides guidance to Claude Code (claude.ai/code) when working with code in this repository.
     4‚Üí
     5‚Üí## Project Overview
     6‚Üí
     7‚ÜíSocialaize is a comprehensive social media management platform that enables users to manage multiple social accounts, schedule posts, analyze performance, and leverage AI for content creation. The platform supports all major social networks including Facebook, Instagram, Twitter/X, LinkedIn, TikTok, YouTube, Pinterest, Mastodon, Threads, and Bluesky.
     8‚Üí
     9‚Üí## Technology Stack
    10‚Üí
    11‚Üí### Frontend
    12‚Üí- **Astro 5.8** - Static site generator with SSR support via Cloudflare Workers
    13‚Üí- **Vue 3** - Component framework with Composition API
    14‚Üí- **TypeScript** - Primary development language
    15‚Üí- **Tailwind CSS 4.1** - Styling framework
    16‚Üí- **Nanostores** - State management
    17‚Üí- **Cloudflare Pages** - Deployment platform
    18‚Üí
    19‚Üí### Backend
    20‚Üí- **Appwrite** - Backend-as-a-Service (database, auth, storage, functions)
    21‚Üí- **Node.js 21** - Primary runtime for serverless functions
    22‚Üí- **Python 3.11** - AI/ML services (FastAPI backend)
    23‚Üí- **Bun** - Fast runtime for specific functions
    24‚Üí
    25‚Üí### AI & Analytics
    26‚Üí- **FastAPI** - Python API service for AI operations
    27‚Üí- **LlamaIndex** - RAG and content processing
    28‚Üí- **Qdrant** - Vector database
    29‚Üí- **Redis** - Caching and chat history
    30‚Üí- **OpenAI** - Content generation
    31‚Üí
    32‚Üí## Common Development Commands
    33‚Üí
    34‚Üí### Main Application
    35‚Üí```bash
    36‚Üí# Development
    37‚Üínpm run dev              # Start local dev server
    38‚Üínpm run start            # Alias for dev
    39‚Üí
    40‚Üí# Building
    41‚Üínpm run build            # Production build
    42‚Üínpm run build:dev        # Development build with dev config
    43‚Üínpm run build:full       # Build with type checking
    44‚Üínpm run preview          # Preview production build
    45‚Üínpm run preview:cf       # Preview with Cloudflare Workers
    46‚Üí
    47‚Üí# Appwrite Setup
    48‚Üínpm run set-appwrite-client  # Configure Appwrite CLI client
    49‚Üí```
    50‚Üí
    51‚Üí### Python AI API (in /api directory)
    52‚Üí```bash
    53‚Üíuv run dev              # Development server
    54‚Üíuv run prod             # Production server
    55‚Üíuv sync                 # Install dependencies
    56‚Üí```
    57‚Üí
    58‚Üí### Appwrite Functions (in each function directory)
    59‚Üí```bash
    60‚Üínpm install             # Install dependencies
    61‚Üínpm run build           # TypeScript compilation
    62‚Üínpm run format          # Code formatting (if available)
    63‚Üí```
    64‚Üí
    65‚Üí## Architecture Overview
    66‚Üí
    67‚Üí### Serverless Functions Architecture
    68‚ÜíThe platform uses **Appwrite Functions** for all backend logic. Each function is self-contained with consistent patterns:
    69‚Üí
    70‚Üí**Function Categories:**
    71‚Üí- **Social Media APIs** - Platform integrations (FacebookApi, InstagramApi, etc.)
    72‚Üí- **Core Management** - Business logic (PostManager, WorkflowManager, SyncManager)
    73‚Üí- **Utilities** - Support services (FileMetadataHandler, EmailHandler, etc.)
    74‚Üí- **AI/ML Services** - Python-based processing (SentimentAnalyzer, VideoDownloader)
    75‚Üí
    76‚Üí**Standard Function Structure:**
    77‚Üí```
    78‚Üífunctions/[FunctionName]/
    79‚Üí‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ src/
    80‚Üí‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ main.ts/js/py     # Entry point
    81‚Üí‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ handlers/         # Business logic
    82‚Üí‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ types/           # TypeScript definitions
    83‚Üí‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ utils/           # Utilities
    84‚Üí‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ constants/       # Configuration
    85‚Üí‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ package.json         # Dependencies and scripts
    86‚Üí‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ tsconfig.json        # TypeScript config
    87‚Üí```
    88‚Üí
    89‚Üí### Database Schema Patterns
    90‚ÜíAll database schemas are defined in TypeScript with comprehensive type safety:
    91‚Üí- Located in `src/appwrite/` for frontend
    92‚Üí- Individual schema files in each function's `types/` directory
    93‚Üí- Extensive use of Zod for runtime validation
    94‚Üí
    95‚Üí### Frontend Architecture
    96‚Üí- **Pages**: Astro pages with SSR capability
    97‚Üí- **Components**: Vue 3 components using Composition API
    98‚Üí- **Stores**: Nanostores for reactive state management
    99‚Üí- **Utilities**: Shared utilities in `src/utils/`
   100‚Üí
   101‚Üí### Analytics System
   102‚ÜíComprehensive analytics dashboard with:
   103‚Üí- **Drag & Drop Interface** - Customizable widget layouts
   104‚Üí- **15+ Chart Types** - Powered by ECharts
   105‚Üí- **Real-time Data** - Dynamic updates and filtering
   106‚Üí- **TypeScript Integration** - Full type safety
   107‚Üí
   108‚Üí## Key Development Patterns
   109‚Üí
   110‚Üí### Error Handling
   111‚Üí- Consistent error handling across all functions
   112‚Üí- Structured logging throughout the application
   113‚Üí- Rate limiting for external API calls
   114‚Üí
   115‚Üí### Authentication & Authorization
   116‚Üí- JWT-based authentication via Appwrite
   117‚Üí- OAuth integration for social platform connections
   118‚Üí- Team-based permission system
   119‚Üí
   120‚Üí### Type Safety
   121‚Üí- End-to-end TypeScript usage
   122‚Üí- Shared schemas between frontend and functions
   123‚Üí- Zod validation for runtime type checking
   124‚Üí
   125‚Üí### Event-Driven Architecture
   126‚Üí- Functions triggered by database events
   127‚Üí- Webhook handling for social platform updates
   128‚Üí- Async processing for long-running tasks
   129‚Üí
   130‚Üí## Working with Appwrite Functions
   131‚Üí
   132‚Üí### Function Development
   133‚Üí1. Each function has its own dependencies and build process
   134‚Üí2. Use `npm run build` to compile TypeScript
   135‚Üí3. Functions are deployed via Appwrite CLI
   136‚Üí4. All functions use `node-appwrite` SDK for database operations
   137‚Üí
   138‚Üí### Function Types by Runtime
   139‚Üí- **Node.js 21**: Most API functions and core logic
   140‚Üí- **Bun**: Performance-critical functions (FileMetadataHandler, utilities)
   141‚Üí- **Python 3.11**: AI/ML functions (SentimentAnalyzer, VideoDownloader)
   142‚Üí
   143‚Üí### Database Events
   144‚ÜíSome functions are triggered by database events (e.g., PostManager responds to post container changes). Check `appwrite.json` for event configurations.
   145‚Üí
   146‚Üí## Testing and Deployment
   147‚Üí
   148‚Üí### Local Development
   149‚Üí- Frontend runs on `localhost:4321` with `npm run dev`
   150‚Üí- Python API typically runs on `localhost:8000` with `uv run dev`
   151‚Üí- Appwrite functions are deployed to cloud environment
   152‚Üí
   153‚Üí### Build Process
   154‚Üí- Use `npm run build:full` for production builds with type checking
   155‚Üí- Each function builds independently with `npm run build`
   156‚Üí- Python API uses `uv` for dependency management
   157‚Üí
   158‚Üí### Cloudflare Integration
   159‚Üí- Frontend deploys to Cloudflare Pages
   160‚Üí- SSR handled by Cloudflare Workers
   161‚Üí- Preview builds available with `npm run build:preview`
   162‚Üí
   163‚Üí## Important Files and Directories
   164‚Üí
   165‚Üí- `appwrite.json` - Defines all 25+ serverless functions and their configurations
   166‚Üí- `src/appwrite/` - Complete TypeScript definitions for all database collections
   167‚Üí- `functions/` - All serverless function implementations
   168‚Üí- `api/` - Python FastAPI service for AI operations
   169‚Üí- `src/components/analytics/` - Analytics dashboard components
   170‚Üí- `AnalyticsReadme.md` - Comprehensive analytics system documentation
   171‚Üí
   172‚Üí## Development Guidelines
   173‚Üí
   174‚Üí### Code Style
   175‚Üí- Use TypeScript throughout
   176‚Üí- Follow existing patterns for error handling and logging
   177‚Üí- Maintain consistent file structure across functions
   178‚Üí- Use Zod schemas for validation
   179‚Üí
   180‚Üí### Adding New Social Platforms
   181‚Üí1. Create new API function in `functions/[Platform]Api/`
   182‚Üí2. Implement OAuth flow in `OAuthManager`
   183‚Üí3. Add database schemas for platform-specific data
   184‚Üí4. Create post converter utilities
   185‚Üí
   186‚Üí### Working with AI Features
   187‚Üí- AI functionality handled by Python FastAPI service in `/api`
   188‚Üí- Uses LlamaIndex for RAG and content processing
   189‚Üí- Vector storage in Qdrant for embeddings
   190‚Üí- Chat history stored in Redis
   191‚Üí
   192‚Üí## Gemini Integration for Large File Analysis
   193‚Üí
   194‚ÜíThis project has Gemini CLI MCP server configured for handling large file analysis that exceeds Claude's context window.
   195‚Üí
   196‚Üí### Auto-Delegation Rules
   197‚Üí
   198‚Üí**ALWAYS use Gemini (`mcp__gemini-cli__ask-gemini`) for:**
   199‚Üí- Files > 500 lines - Automatically delegate to Gemini with @file syntax
   200‚Üí- Multiple file analysis (3+ files) - Have Gemini analyze all files together
   201‚Üí- Entire directory analysis - Use Gemini to scan and summarize patterns
   202‚Üí- Type definition files (.d.ts) - Gemini handles large type files efficiently
   203‚Üí- Generated files (dist/, build/) - Gemini's context handles large generated code
   204‚Üí- Log files or data files - Gemini can process massive logs/data
   205‚Üí- **Web searches during code analysis** - Gemini can search while analyzing files
   206‚Üí- **Research + implementation combos** - Search for best practices then compare with code
   207‚Üí
   208‚Üí### Usage Pattern
   209‚Üí```typescript
   210‚Üí// For single large file
   211‚Üímcp__gemini-cli__ask-gemini("@path/to/large-file.ts What patterns are used?")
   212‚Üí
   213‚Üí// For multiple files
   214‚Üímcp__gemini-cli__ask-gemini("@file1.ts @file2.ts @file3.ts Compare these implementations")
   215‚Üí
   216‚Üí// For directory analysis
   217‚Üímcp__gemini-cli__ask-gemini("@src/components/**/*.vue Analyze all Vue components")
   218‚Üí
   219‚Üí// Web search for quick facts
   220‚Üímcp__gemini-cli__ask-gemini("Search for latest Vue 3.5 breaking changes 2025")
   221‚Üí
   222‚Üí// Code analysis + web research combo
   223‚Üímcp__gemini-cli__ask-gemini("@src/auth/jwt.ts Search for JWT security best practices 2025 and compare with this implementation")
   224‚Üí
   225‚Üí// Research while analyzing multiple files
   226‚Üímcp__gemini-cli__ask-gemini("@functions/PostManager/* Search for post scheduling patterns and analyze how this implementation compares")
   227‚Üí```
   228‚Üí
   229‚Üí### Workflow Strategy
   230‚Üí1. **Gemini analyzes + researches** ‚Üí Reads large files, searches web for best practices, identifies patterns
   231‚Üí2. **Claude implements** ‚Üí Generates code, fixes bugs, refactors based on Gemini's findings
   232‚Üí3. **Best of both**: Gemini's 1M+ token context + web search + Claude's reasoning & code generation
   233‚Üí
   234‚Üí### When to Use Gemini
   235‚Üí- ‚úÖ Before refactoring large files - Get Gemini's analysis first
   236‚Üí- ‚úÖ When user asks about file structure/patterns - Delegate to Gemini
   237‚Üí- ‚úÖ For codebase-wide searches - Gemini can scan entire directories
   238‚Üí- ‚úÖ When context window fills up - Offload reading to Gemini
   239‚Üí- ‚úÖ **Quick web searches** - Gemini searches faster than Claude's WebSearch for facts
   240‚Üí- ‚úÖ **Research + code analysis together** - Compare code against latest best practices
   241‚Üí- ‚úÖ **Real-time API/framework updates** - Check latest features while analyzing code
   242‚Üí- ‚ùå For code generation - Use Claude's strengths
   243‚Üí- ‚ùå For small files (<500 lines) - Use Claude's Read tool
   244‚Üí- ‚ùå For comprehensive research reports - Use Claude's `/web-search` command instead
   245‚Üí
   246‚Üí## Package Management
   247‚Üí- **Frontend**: PNPM (specified in package.json)
   248‚Üí- **Python API**: UV (modern Python package manager)
   249‚Üí- **Functions**: NPM (individual package.json files)
   250‚Üí
   251‚Üí
   252‚Üí
   253‚Üí
   254‚Üí<!--CLAUDEMCPTOOLS_INTEGRATION_START-->
   255‚Üí# ClaudeMcpTools Integration
   256‚Üí
   257‚ÜíThis project uses ClaudeMcpTools with enhanced MCP tools for development.
   258‚Üí
   259‚Üí## Quick Start Commands
   260‚Üí
   261‚Üí### Smart File Operations
   262‚Üí- `list_files(directory=".")` - List files with smart ignore patterns
   263‚Üí- `find_files(pattern="*.py")` - Search files by pattern  
   264‚Üí- `easy_replace(file_path, old_text, new_text)` - Fuzzy string replacement
   265‚Üí- `take_screenshot()` - Cross-platform screenshots
   266‚Üí
   267‚Üí### Project Analysis
   268‚Üí- `analyze_project_structure(project_path=".")` - Generate .treesummary files
   269‚Üí- `generate_project_summary(project_path=".")` - AI-optimized project overview
   270‚Üí- `detect_dead_code(project_path=".")` - Find unused code
   271‚Üí
   272‚Üí### Documentation Intelligence  
   273‚Üí- `scrape_documentation(url="https://docs.example.com")` - Scrape and index docs
   274‚Üí- `search_documentation(query="API usage")` - Semantic search with AI
   275‚Üí- `link_docs_to_code(project_path=".")` - Connect docs to code
   276‚Üí
   277‚Üí### Multi-Agent Workflows
   278‚Üí- `spawn_agent(agent_type="implementer", repository_path=".")` - Create specialized agents
   279‚Üí- `create_task(repository_path=".", task_type="feature")` - Coordinate development tasks
   280‚Üí- `join_room(room_name="dev-team")` - Real-time agent communication
   281‚Üí
   282‚Üí### Shared Memory & Error Logging
   283‚Üí- `store_memory_entry(repository_path=".", agent_id, entry_type="insight", title, content)` - Store insights for other agents
   284‚Üí- `query_shared_memory(repository_path=".", query_text="authentication")` - Search previous agent work
   285‚Üí- `store_agent_insight(repository_path=".", agent_id, insight_type="pattern", category="architecture", title, description)` - Share discoveries
   286‚Üí- `log_error(repository_path=".", error_type="runtime", error_category="mcp_tool", error_message)` - Enhanced error logging
   287‚Üí- `get_error_patterns(repository_path=".")` - Learn from previous failures
   288‚Üí- `get_recent_errors(repository_path=".")` - Debug current issues
   289‚Üí
   290‚Üí## Agent Collaboration Features
   291‚Üí
   292‚Üí### Cross-Agent Memory
   293‚ÜíAgents can store and share discoveries, tool results, and insights:
   294‚Üí```
   295‚Üí# Store a discovery for other agents
   296‚Üístore_memory_entry(
   297‚Üí    repository_path=".",
   298‚Üí    agent_id="agent-123", 
   299‚Üí    entry_type="discovery",
   300‚Üí    title="Authentication Pattern Found",
   301‚Üí    content="Project uses JWT with refresh tokens in src/auth/",
   302‚Üí    tags=["authentication", "security", "jwt"]
   303‚Üí)
   304‚Üí
   305‚Üí# Query previous agent work
   306‚Üíquery_shared_memory(
   307‚Üí    repository_path=".",
   308‚Üí    query_text="authentication patterns",
   309‚Üí    entry_types=["discovery", "insight"]
   310‚Üí)
   311‚Üí```
   312‚Üí
   313‚Üí### Error Learning System
   314‚ÜíComprehensive error tracking with pattern recognition:
   315‚Üí```
   316‚Üí# Log errors with full context
   317‚Üílog_error(
   318‚Üí    repository_path=".",
   319‚Üí    error_type="runtime",
   320‚Üí    error_category="file_operation", 
   321‚Üí    error_message="Permission denied accessing config.json",
   322‚Üí    context={"file_path": "./config.json", "operation": "read"},
   323‚Üí    attempted_solution="Tried chmod 644"
   324‚Üí)
   325‚Üí
   326‚Üí# Learn from patterns
   327‚Üíget_error_patterns(repository_path=".", min_frequency=2)
   328‚Üí```
   329‚Üí
   330‚Üí## Usage Patterns
   331‚Üí
   332‚Üí**Quick Analysis**: "Please analyze_project_structure to understand this codebase"
   333‚Üí**Multi-Agent Feature**: "Spawn agents to implement user auth with tests and docs"

   345‚Üí# ClaudeMcpTools Agent Operations Guide

   354‚Üí- Full-stack implementations (backend + frontend + tests)
   355‚Üí- Complex features requiring multiple specializations

   421‚Üí### Agent Specialization Types

   423‚Üí- **`frontend`** - UI components, state management, user experience

   425‚Üí- **`documentation`** - Technical writing, API docs, README files
   426‚Üí- **`devops`** - CI/CD, deployment, infrastructure
   427‚Üí- **`analysis`** - Code review, performance analysis, architecture

   429‚Üí## üíæ Knowledge Management Workflows
   430‚Üí

# CLAUDE.md

This file provides guidance to Claude Code (claude.ai/code) when working with code in this repository.

## Project Overview

Socialaize is a comprehensive social media management platform that enables users to manage multiple social accounts, schedule posts, analyze performance, and leverage AI for content creation. The platform supports all major social networks including Facebook, Instagram, Twitter/X, LinkedIn, TikTok, YouTube, Pinterest, Mastodon, Threads, and Bluesky.

## Technology Stack

### Frontend
- **Astro 5.8** - Static site generator with SSR support via Cloudflare Workers
- **Vue 3** - Component framework with Composition API
- **TypeScript** - Primary development language
- **Tailwind CSS 4.1** - Styling framework
- **Nanostores** - State management
- **Cloudflare Pages** - Deployment platform

### Backend
- **Appwrite** - Backend-as-a-Service (database, auth, storage, functions)
- **Node.js 21** - Primary runtime for serverless functions
- **Python 3.11** - AI/ML services (FastAPI backend)
- **Bun** - Fast runtime for specific functions

### AI & Analytics
- **FastAPI** - Python API service for AI operations
- **LlamaIndex** - RAG and content processing
- **Qdrant** - Vector database
- **Redis** - Caching and chat history
- **OpenAI** - Content generation

## Common Development Commands

### Main Application
```bash
# Development
npm run dev              # Start local dev server
npm run start            # Alias for dev

# Building
npm run build            # Production build
npm run build:dev        # Development build with dev config
npm run build:full       # Build with type checking
npm run preview          # Preview production build
npm run preview:cf       # Preview with Cloudflare Workers

# Appwrite Setup
npm run set-appwrite-client  # Configure Appwrite CLI client
```

### Python AI API (in /api directory)
```bash
uv run dev              # Development server
uv run prod             # Production server
uv sync                 # Install dependencies
```

### Appwrite Functions (in each function directory)
```bash
npm install             # Install dependencies
npm run build           # TypeScript compilation
npm run format          # Code formatting (if available)
```

## Architecture Overview

### Serverless Functions Architecture
The platform uses **Appwrite Functions** for all backend logic. Each function is self-contained with consistent patterns:

**Function Categories:**
- **Social Media APIs** - Platform integrations (FacebookApi, InstagramApi, etc.)
- **Core Management** - Business logic (PostManager, WorkflowManager, SyncManager)
- **Utilities** - Support services (FileMetadataHandler, EmailHandler, etc.)
- **AI/ML Services** - Python-based processing (SentimentAnalyzer, VideoDownloader)

**Standard Function Structure:**
```
functions/[FunctionName]/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ src/
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ main.ts/js/py     # Entry point
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ handlers/         # Business logic
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ types/           # TypeScript definitions
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ utils/           # Utilities
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ constants/       # Configuration
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ package.json         # Dependencies and scripts
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ tsconfig.json        # TypeScript config
```

### Database Schema Patterns
All database schemas are defined in TypeScript with comprehensive type safety:
- Located in `src/appwrite/` for frontend
- Individual schema files in each function's `types/` directory
- Extensive use of Zod for runtime validation

### Frontend Architecture
- **Pages**: Astro pages with SSR capability
- **Components**: Vue 3 components using Composition API
- **Stores**: Nanostores for reactive state management
- **Utilities**: Shared utilities in `src/utils/`

### Analytics System
Comprehensive analytics dashboard with:
- **Drag & Drop Interface** - Customizable widget layouts
- **15+ Chart Types** - Powered by ECharts
- **Real-time Data** - Dynamic updates and filtering
- **TypeScript Integration** - Full type safety

## Key Development Patterns

### Error Handling
- Consistent error handling across all functions
- Structured logging throughout the application
- Rate limiting for external API calls

### Authentication & Authorization
- JWT-based authentication via Appwrite
- OAuth integration for social platform connections
- Team-based permission system

### Type Safety
- End-to-end TypeScript usage
- Shared schemas between frontend and functions
- Zod validation for runtime type checking

### Event-Driven Architecture
- Functions triggered by database events
- Webhook handling for social platform updates
- Async processing for long-running tasks

## Working with Appwrite Functions

### Function Development
1. Each function has its own dependencies and build process
2. Use `npm run build` to compile TypeScript
3. Functions are deployed via Appwrite CLI
4. All functions use `node-appwrite` SDK for database operations

### Function Types by Runtime
- **Node.js 21**: Most API functions and core logic
- **Bun**: Performance-critical functions (FileMetadataHandler, utilities)
- **Python 3.11**: AI/ML functions (SentimentAnalyzer, VideoDownloader)

### Database Events
Some functions are triggered by database events (e.g., PostManager responds to post container changes). Check `appwrite.json` for event configurations.

## Testing and Deployment

### Local Development
- Frontend runs on `localhost:4321` with `npm run dev`
- Python API typically runs on `localhost:8000` with `uv run dev`
- Appwrite functions are deployed to cloud environment

### Build Process
- Use `npm run build:full` for production builds with type checking
- Each function builds independently with `npm run build`
- Python API uses `uv` for dependency management

### Cloudflare Integration
- Frontend deploys to Cloudflare Pages
- SSR handled by Cloudflare Workers
- Preview builds available with `npm run build:preview`

## Important Files and Directories

- `appwrite.json` - Defines all 25+ serverless functions and their configurations
- `src/appwrite/` - Complete TypeScript definitions for all database collections
- `functions/` - All serverless function implementations
- `api/` - Python FastAPI service for AI operations
- `src/components/analytics/` - Analytics dashboard components
- `AnalyticsReadme.md` - Comprehensive analytics system documentation

## Development Guidelines

### Code Style
- Use TypeScript throughout
- Follow existing patterns for error handling and logging
- Maintain consistent file structure across functions
- Use Zod schemas for validation

### Adding New Social Platforms
1. Create new API function in `functions/[Platform]Api/`
2. Implement OAuth flow in `OAuthManager`
3. Add database schemas for platform-specific data
4. Create post converter utilities

### Working with AI Features
- AI functionality handled by Python FastAPI service in `/api`
- Uses LlamaIndex for RAG and content processing
- Vector storage in Qdrant for embeddings
- Chat history stored in Redis

## Gemini Integration for Large File Analysis

This project has Gemini CLI MCP server configured for handling large file analysis that exceeds Claude's context window.

### Auto-Delegation Rules

**ALWAYS use Gemini (`mcp__gemini-cli__ask-gemini`) for:**
- Files > 500 lines - Automatically delegate to Gemini with @file syntax
- Multiple file analysis (3+ files) - Have Gemini analyze all files together
- Entire directory analysis - Use Gemini to scan and summarize patterns
- Type definition files (.d.ts) - Gemini handles large type files efficiently
- Generated files (dist/, build/) - Gemini's context handles large generated code
- Log files or data files - Gemini can process massive logs/data
- **Web searches during code analysis** - Gemini can search while analyzing files
- **Research + implementation combos** - Search for best practices then compare with code

### Usage Pattern
```typescript
// For single large file
mcp__gemini-cli__ask-gemini("@path/to/large-file.ts What patterns are used?")

// For multiple files
mcp__gemini-cli__ask-gemini("@file1.ts @file2.ts @file3.ts Compare these implementations")

// For directory analysis
mcp__gemini-cli__ask-gemini("@src/components/**/*.vue Analyze all Vue components")

// Web search for quick facts
mcp__gemini-cli__ask-gemini("Search for latest Vue 3.5 breaking changes 2025")

// Code analysis + web research combo
mcp__gemini-cli__ask-gemini("@src/auth/jwt.ts Search for JWT security best practices 2025 and compare with this implementation")

// Research while analyzing multiple files
mcp__gemini-cli__ask-gemini("@functions/PostManager/* Search for post scheduling patterns and analyze how this implementation compares")
```

### Workflow Strategy
1. **Gemini analyzes + researches** ‚Üí Reads large files, searches web for best practices, identifies patterns
2. **Claude implements** ‚Üí Generates code, fixes bugs, refactors based on Gemini's findings
3. **Best of both**: Gemini's 1M+ token context + web search + Claude's reasoning & code generation

### When to Use Gemini
- ‚úÖ Before refactoring large files - Get Gemini's analysis first
- ‚úÖ When user asks about file structure/patterns - Delegate to Gemini
- ‚úÖ For codebase-wide searches - Gemini can scan entire directories
- ‚úÖ When context window fills up - Offload reading to Gemini
- ‚úÖ **Quick web searches** - Gemini searches faster than Claude's WebSearch for facts
- ‚úÖ **Research + code analysis together** - Compare code against latest best practices
- ‚úÖ **Real-time API/framework updates** - Check latest features while analyzing code
- ‚ùå For code generation - Use Claude's strengths
- ‚ùå For small files (<500 lines) - Use Claude's Read tool
- ‚ùå For comprehensive research reports - Use Claude's `/web-search` command instead

## Package Management
- **Frontend**: PNPM (specified in package.json)
- **Python API**: UV (modern Python package manager)
- **Functions**: NPM (individual package.json files)

# ClaudeMcpTools Integration

This project uses ClaudeMcpTools with enhanced MCP tools for development.

## Quick Start Commands

### Smart File Operations
- `list_files(directory=".")` - List files with smart ignore patterns
- `find_files(pattern="*.py")` - Search files by pattern  
- `easy_replace(file_path, old_text, new_text)` - Fuzzy string replacement
- `take_screenshot()` - Cross-platform screenshots

### Project Analysis
- `analyze_project_structure(project_path=".")` - Generate .treesummary files
- `generate_project_summary(project_path=".")` - AI-optimized project overview
- `detect_dead_code(project_path=".")` - Find unused code

### Documentation Intelligence  
- `scrape_documentation(url="https://docs.example.com")` - Scrape and index docs
- `search_documentation(query="API usage")` - Semantic search with AI
- `link_docs_to_code(project_path=".")` - Connect docs to code

### Multi-Agent Workflows
- `spawn_agent(agent_type="implementer", repository_path=".")` - Create specialized agents
- `create_task(repository_path=".", task_type="feature")` - Coordinate development tasks
- `join_room(room_name="dev-team")` - Real-time agent communication

### Shared Memory & Error Logging
- `store_memory_entry(repository_path=".", agent_id, entry_type="insight", title, content)` - Store insights for other agents
- `query_shared_memory(repository_path=".", query_text="authentication")` - Search previous agent work
- `store_agent_insight(repository_path=".", agent_id, insight_type="pattern", category="architecture", title, description)` - Share discoveries
- `log_error(repository_path=".", error_type="runtime", error_category="mcp_tool", error_message)` - Enhanced error logging
- `get_error_patterns(repository_path=".")` - Learn from previous failures
- `get_recent_errors(repository_path=".")` - Debug current issues

## Agent Collaboration Features

### Cross-Agent Memory
Agents can store and share discoveries, tool results, and insights:
```
# Store a discovery for other agents
store_memory_entry(
    repository_path=".",
    agent_id="agent-123", 
    entry_type="discovery",
    title="Authentication Pattern Found",
    content="Project uses JWT with refresh tokens in src/auth/",
    tags=["authentication", "security", "jwt"]
)

# Query previous agent work
query_shared_memory(
    repository_path=".",
    query_text="authentication patterns",
    entry_types=["discovery", "insight"]
)
```

### Error Learning System
Comprehensive error tracking with pattern recognition:
```
# Log errors with full context
log_error(
    repository_path=".",
    error_type="runtime",
    error_category="file_operation", 
    error_message="Permission denied accessing config.json",
    context={"file_path": "./config.json", "operation": "read"},
    attempted_solution="Tried chmod 644"
)

# Learn from patterns
get_error_patterns(repository_path=".", min_frequency=2)
```

## Usage Patterns

**Quick Analysis**: "Please analyze_project_structure to understand this codebase"
**Multi-Agent Feature**: "Spawn agents to implement user auth with tests and docs"
**Documentation Setup**: "Scrape the React docs and make them searchable locally"
**Smart Search**: "Find all files that import the authentication module"
**Collaborative Development**: "Store your findings in shared memory for other agents to reference"
**Error Analysis**: "Check recent errors and their patterns to avoid repeating issues"

Data stored locally at `~/.claude/zmcptools/` with 85-90% token cost reduction via caching.

# ClaudeMcpTools Agent Operations Guide

This guide provides actionable workflows for Claude agents using the ClaudeMcpTools MCP toolset for autonomous development.

## üß† Agent Decision Framework

### When to Use Multi-Agent Orchestration
**ALWAYS use `orchestrate_objective()` for:**
- Tasks requiring 3+ sequential steps
- Full-stack implementations (backend + frontend + tests)
- Complex features requiring multiple specializations
- Documentation scraping + implementation workflows
- Development environment setup + testing

**Use single-agent tools for:**
- Simple file operations
- Quick analysis or investigation
- Single-purpose tasks under 30 minutes

### Foundation Caching Strategy
**Critical for cost optimization:**
```typescript
// Use shared foundation sessions for 85-90% cost reduction
orchestrate_objective(
  "your complex objective",
  ".",
  { foundation_session_id: "project-feature-name-2024" }
)
```

## üéØ Multi-Agent Coordination Patterns

### 1. Full-Stack Development Pattern
```typescript
// Architect coordinates: Backend ‚Üí Frontend ‚Üí Testing ‚Üí Documentation
orchestrate_objective(
  "Implement user authentication with JWT tokens, React login UI, comprehensive tests, and API documentation",
  "."
)
```

### 2. Documentation-First Pattern
```typescript
// Phase 1: Research and documentation scraping
scrape_documentation("https://docs.framework.com", { max_pages: 50 })
search_knowledge_graph(".", "authentication best practices")

// Phase 2: Implementation following documentation patterns
orchestrate_objective(
  "Build authentication system following scraped framework documentation patterns",
  "."
)
```

### 3. Analysis ‚Üí Implementation Pattern
```typescript
// Phase 1: Project analysis
analyze_project_structure(".")
generate_project_summary(".")

// Phase 2: Coordinated implementation
orchestrate_objective(
  "Refactor codebase based on analysis findings and implement missing features",
  "."
)
```

## üîÑ Sequential Task Management

### Complex Task Breakdown
1. **Start with `create_task()`** - Define the high-level goal
2. **Use `orchestrate_objective()`** - Let architect break down subtasks
3. **Monitor with `list_agents()`** - Track progress
4. **Coordinate via `join_room()`** - Real-time communication
5. **Store insights with `store_knowledge_memory()`** - Cross-agent learning

### Agent Specialization Types
- **`backend`** - API development, database design, server logic
- **`frontend`** - UI components, state management, user experience
- **`testing`** - Unit tests, integration tests, E2E testing
- **`documentation`** - Technical writing, API docs, README files
- **`devops`** - CI/CD, deployment, infrastructure
- **`analysis`** - Code review, performance analysis, architecture

## üíæ Knowledge Management Workflows

### Before Implementation - Always Research
```typescript
// 1. Search existing knowledge
const insights = await search_knowledge_graph(".", "similar feature implementation")

// 2. Scrape relevant documentation if needed
await scrape_documentation("https://relevant-docs.com")

// 3. Analyze current project structure
await analyze_project_structure(".")
```

### During Implementation - Store Learnings
```typescript
// Store insights for other agents
await store_knowledge_memory(".", agent_id, "technical_decision", 
  "Database Schema Design",
  "Chose PostgreSQL with JSONB for user preferences due to flexible schema needs"
)

// Store error patterns
await store_knowledge_memory(".", agent_id, "error_pattern",
  "React State Management",
  "useState hooks caused re-render issues, switched to useReducer for complex state"
)
```

### After Implementation - Document Outcomes
```typescript
// Store implementation patterns for future use
await store_knowledge_memory(".", agent_id, "implementation_pattern",
  "JWT Authentication Flow",
  "Successful pattern: JWT in httpOnly cookies + CSRF tokens for security"
)
```

## üö® Error Recovery Patterns

### When Tasks Fail
1. **Check agent status**: `list_agents(".", "failed")`
2. **Review error logs**: Check shared memory for error patterns
3. **Restart with lessons learned**: Use previous insights in new objective
4. **Isolate problems**: Use single-agent tools for debugging

### Common Recovery Actions
```typescript
// If orchestration fails, break down manually
const task1 = await create_task(".", "research", "Investigate failed component")
const agent1 = await spawn_agent("analysis", ".", "Debug the failing authentication flow")

// Use room coordination for complex debugging
await join_room("debug-session-" + Date.now())
await send_message("debug-session", "Agent investigating auth flow failure", ["analysis-agent"])
```

## üé® Agent-Type-Specific Workflows

### Backend Agent Actions
1. Design database schema first
2. Implement core business logic
3. Create API endpoints with proper validation
4. Store API patterns in knowledge graph
5. Coordinate with frontend agent via shared memory

### Frontend Agent Actions  
1. Review backend API specifications from shared memory
2. Create reusable components following project patterns
3. Implement state management
4. Store UI patterns for consistency
5. Coordinate with testing agent for component tests

### Testing Agent Actions
1. Wait for implementation completion (use agent dependencies)
2. Create comprehensive test suites
3. Run tests and store failure patterns
4. Provide feedback to implementation agents
5. Document testing strategies in knowledge graph

### Documentation Agent Actions
1. Wait for feature completion
2. Generate API documentation from code
3. Create user guides and examples
4. Store documentation patterns
5. Ensure consistency across project docs

## üîß Tool Usage Priorities

### Phase 1: Analysis (Always First)
1. `analyze_project_structure(".")` - Understand codebase
2. `search_knowledge_graph(".", "relevant query")` - Check existing knowledge
3. `scrape_documentation()` - Get external context if needed

### Phase 2: Planning
1. `create_task()` - Define objectives
2. `orchestrate_objective()` - Break down complex work
3. `join_room()` - Set up coordination

### Phase 3: Implementation
1. Agent-specific tools (`spawn_agent()`, specialized workflows)
2. `store_knowledge_memory()` - Continuous learning
3. `send_message()` - Cross-agent coordination

### Phase 4: Validation
1. `list_agents()` - Check completion status
2. Review stored insights and learnings
3. Run tests and validate implementation

## üí° Best Practices

### Always Do This
- Start complex tasks with `orchestrate_objective()`
- Use foundation sessions for cost optimization
- Store insights immediately when discovered
- Check existing knowledge before implementing
- Coordinate agents via shared rooms

### Never Do This
- Implement without analysis phase
- Skip documentation scraping for new frameworks
- Ignore shared memory from other agents
- Start multiple agents without coordination
- Forget to store learnings for future agents

### Foundation Session Optimization
- Use descriptive session IDs: "auth-system-v2-2024"
- Share sessions across related agents (85-90% cost reduction)
- Include version numbers for iterative development
- Name sessions after major features or epics

## üöÄ Quick Start Checklist

For any new complex task:
1. ‚úÖ `analyze_project_structure(".")` - Understand the codebase
2. ‚úÖ `search_knowledge_graph(".", "task-related-query")` - Check existing work
3. ‚úÖ `orchestrate_objective("clear objective", ".", {foundation_session_id: "descriptive-name"})` - Coordinate implementation
4. ‚úÖ `join_room("task-coordination")` - Monitor progress
5. ‚úÖ `store_knowledge_memory()` - Document learnings throughout

**Data Location**: `~/.mcptools/data/` (SQLite databases with agent coordination, shared memory, and knowledge graphs)

üéØ **Core Principle**: Always use multi-agent orchestration for complex tasks. Single agents are for investigation and simple operations only.

## Package Management
- **Frontend**: PNPM (specified in package.json)
- **Python API**: UV (modern Python package manager)
- **Functions**: NPM (individual package.json files)

## MCP Tool Usage Guidelines

This project has several MCP servers configured for enhanced development capabilities. Use these tools strategically based on the task at hand.

### GitHub Documentation Tool (`mcp__github-docs__*`)

**Purpose**: Search and fetch documentation from GitHub repositories.

**Available Tools**:
- `match_common_libs_owner_repo_mapping(library)` - Map library names to GitHub repos (e.g., "react" ‚Üí "reactjs/react.dev")
- `fetch_generic_documentation(owner, repo)` - Fetch README/docs from a repo
- `search_generic_documentation(owner, repo, query)` - Semantic search within docs (requires indexing)
- `search_generic_code(owner, repo, query, page?)` - Search code files with pagination (30 results/page)
- `fetch_generic_url_content(url)` - Fetch content from specific GitHub URLs (‚ö†Ô∏è limited to 64K tokens)

**When to Use**:
- Finding which files contain specific APIs, patterns, or features in framework docs
- Discovering example usage across official documentation repos
- Understanding framework integration patterns
- Locating where specific features are documented

**Best Practices**:
```typescript
// 1. Map library name to repo
mcp__github-docs__match_common_libs_owner_repo_mapping({ library: "astro" })
// Returns: { owner: "withastro", repo: "docs" }

// 2. Search for specific patterns
mcp__github-docs__search_generic_code({
  owner: "withastro",
  repo: "docs",
  query: "client:load directive"
})
// Returns: 77 matches with file paths and URLs

// 3. Use pagination for more results
mcp__github-docs__search_generic_code({
  owner: "reactjs",
  repo: "react.dev",
  query: "useState",
  page: 2
})
```

**Limitations**:
- `fetch_generic_url_content` cannot fetch files >64K tokens
- Semantic search requires documentation to be indexed
- Returns file paths, not actual content (use Read tool after discovery)

### Tailwind CSS Tool (`mcp__tailwind__*`)

**Purpose**: Access Tailwind CSS utilities, colors, and configuration without leaving the editor.

**Available Tools**:
- `get_tailwind_utilities(category?, property?, search?)` - Get utility classes
- `get_tailwind_colors(colorName?, includeShades?)` - Get color palette info
- `get_tailwind_config_guide(framework?, topic?)` - Get config guides for specific frameworks
- `search_tailwind_docs(query, category?, limit?)` - Search Tailwind documentation
- `install_tailwind(framework, packageManager?, includeTypescript?)` - Generate install commands
- `convert_css_to_tailwind(css, mode?)` - Convert CSS to Tailwind utilities
- `generate_color_palette(baseColor, name, shades?)` - Create custom color palettes
- `generate_component_template(componentType, style?, responsive?, darkMode?)` - Generate component templates

**When to Use**:
- Need quick reference to Tailwind utilities while styling
- Converting existing CSS to Tailwind classes
- Setting up Tailwind in a new framework
- Generating consistent color palettes
- Creating common UI component templates

**Best Practices**:
```typescript
// Search for specific utilities
mcp__tailwind__get_tailwind_utilities({ search: "flex gap" })

// Convert CSS to Tailwind
mcp__tailwind__convert_css_to_tailwind({
  css: "display: flex; gap: 1rem; padding: 2rem;",
  mode: "classes" // or "inline" or "component"
})

// Generate component templates
mcp__tailwind__generate_component_template({
  componentType: "button",
  style: "modern",
  responsive: true,
  darkMode: true
})

// Create color palette from brand color
mcp__tailwind__generate_color_palette({
  baseColor: "#4F46E5",
  name: "brand",
  shades: [50, 100, 200, 300, 400, 500, 600, 700, 800, 900, 950]
})
```

### Firecrawl Tool (`mcp__firecrawl__*`)

**Purpose**: Powerful web scraping and search with content extraction.

**Available Tools**:
- `firecrawl_scrape(url, formats?, maxAge?)` - Scrape single page (fastest, use `maxAge` for caching)
- `firecrawl_search(query, limit?, sources?, scrapeOptions?)` - Search web and extract content
- `firecrawl_map(url, limit?, search?)` - Discover all URLs on a website
- `firecrawl_crawl(url, limit?, maxDiscoveryDepth?)` - Crawl entire site (‚ö†Ô∏è can be very large)
- `firecrawl_extract(urls[], prompt?, schema?)` - Extract structured data using LLM
- `firecrawl_check_crawl_status(id)` - Check crawl job progress

**When to Use**:
- Research latest framework/API changes not in Claude's training data
- Scrape competitor features or design patterns
- Extract structured data from multiple pages
- Discover site structure before targeted scraping
- Need content with images, markdown, or HTML formats

**Best Practices**:
```typescript
// Fast single page scrape with caching
mcp__firecrawl__firecrawl_scrape({
  url: "https://example.com/docs/api",
  formats: ["markdown"],
  maxAge: 172800000 // 48 hours (500% faster)
})

// Web search with content extraction
mcp__firecrawl__firecrawl_search({
  query: "Vue 3 Composition API best practices 2025",
  limit: 5,
  sources: [{ type: "web" }],
  scrapeOptions: {
    formats: ["markdown"],
    onlyMainContent: true
  }
})

// Map site before scraping
mcp__firecrawl__firecrawl_map({
  url: "https://docs.example.com",
  search: "api-reference" // Optional filter
})

// Extract structured data
mcp__firecrawl__firecrawl_extract({
  urls: ["https://example.com/product1", "https://example.com/product2"],
  schema: {
    name: { type: "string" },
    price: { type: "number" },
    description: { type: "string" }
  }
})
```

**Limitations**:
- Crawl responses can exceed token limits (use `map` + targeted `scrape` instead)
- Respect robots.txt and rate limits
- Search results quality depends on query specificity

### Playwright Tool (`mcp__playwright__*`)

**Purpose**: Browser automation for testing, scraping dynamic content, and UI interactions.

**Available Tools**:
- `browser_navigate(url)` - Navigate to URL
- `browser_snapshot()` - Capture accessibility snapshot (better than screenshots for actions)
- `browser_take_screenshot(filename?, fullPage?, type?)` - Take visual screenshot
- `browser_click(element, ref, button?, modifiers?)` - Click elements
- `browser_type(element, ref, text, slowly?, submit?)` - Type into inputs
- `browser_fill_form(fields[])` - Fill multiple form fields at once
- `browser_select_option(element, ref, values[])` - Select dropdown options
- `browser_evaluate(function, element?, ref?)` - Execute JavaScript
- `browser_wait_for(text?, textGone?, time?)` - Wait for conditions
- `browser_tabs(action, index?)` - Manage browser tabs
- `browser_console_messages()` - Get console output
- `browser_network_requests()` - Inspect network traffic

**When to Use**:
- Test user workflows end-to-end
- Scrape JavaScript-rendered content
- Validate responsive designs across viewports
- Debug frontend issues in real browser environment
- Automate repetitive UI testing tasks
- Inspect network requests and console logs

**Best Practices**:
```typescript
// Navigate and capture state
mcp__playwright__browser_navigate({ url: "https://app.example.com" })
mcp__playwright__browser_snapshot() // For planning actions

// Fill and submit forms
mcp__playwright__browser_fill_form({
  fields: [
    { name: "email", type: "textbox", ref: "input#email", value: "test@example.com" },
    { name: "password", type: "textbox", ref: "input#password", value: "password123" },
    { name: "remember", type: "checkbox", ref: "input#remember", value: "true" }
  ]
})
mcp__playwright__browser_click({
  element: "submit button",
  ref: "button[type=submit]"
})

// Wait for results and capture
mcp__playwright__browser_wait_for({ text: "Welcome" })
mcp__playwright__browser_take_screenshot({
  filename: "logged-in.png",
  fullPage: true
})

// Debug with console/network
mcp__playwright__browser_console_messages()
mcp__playwright__browser_network_requests()

// Execute custom JavaScript
mcp__playwright__browser_evaluate({
  function: "() => document.querySelector('.user-name').textContent"
})

// Manage multiple tabs
mcp__playwright__browser_tabs({ action: "new" })
mcp__playwright__browser_tabs({ action: "select", index: 0 })
```

**Limitations**:
- Requires explicit user permission for interactions
- Screenshots are visual only (use `browser_snapshot` for actions)
- Long operations may timeout (use `wait_for` appropriately)
- Single browser instance per session

### Tool Selection Strategy

**For Documentation Research**:
1. Start with `mcp__github-docs__search_generic_code` to find relevant files
2. Use `Read` tool to examine specific files found
3. Use `mcp__firecrawl__firecrawl_search` for content not in GitHub repos

**For Web Research**:
1. Use `mcp__firecrawl__firecrawl_search` for quick searches with content
2. Use `mcp__firecrawl__firecrawl_scrape` for specific pages (with `maxAge` for speed)
3. Use `mcp__firecrawl__firecrawl_map` to discover before crawling
4. Use `mcp__playwright__browser_navigate` for JavaScript-heavy sites

**For UI Development**:
1. Use `mcp__tailwind__*` tools for styling utilities and references
2. Use `mcp__tailwind__convert_css_to_tailwind` when refactoring
3. Use `mcp__tailwind__generate_component_template` for consistent UI patterns
4. Use `mcp__playwright__*` tools to test final implementations

**For Testing**:
1. Use `mcp__playwright__browser_*` for E2E user flow testing
2. Use `browser_snapshot()` to plan test steps
3. Use `browser_console_messages()` and `browser_network_requests()` for debugging

**Purpose**: Search and fetch documentation from GitHub repositories.

**Available Tools**:
- `match_common_libs_owner_repo_mapping(library)` - Map library names to GitHub repos (e.g., "react" ‚Üí "reactjs/react.dev")
- `fetch_generic_documentation(owner, repo)` - Fetch README/docs from a repo
- `search_generic_documentation(owner, repo, query)` - Semantic search within docs (requires indexing)
- `search_generic_code(owner, repo, query, page?)` - Search code files with pagination (30 results/page)
- `fetch_generic_url_content(url)` - Fetch content from specific GitHub URLs (‚ö†Ô∏è limited to 64K tokens)

**When to Use**:
- Finding which files contain specific APIs, patterns, or features in framework docs
- Discovering example usage across official documentation repos
- Understanding framework integration patterns
- Locating where specific features are documented

**Best Practices**:
```typescript
// 1. Map library name to repo
mcp__github-docs__match_common_libs_owner_repo_mapping({ library: "astro" })
// Returns: { owner: "withastro", repo: "docs" }

// 2. Search for specific patterns
mcp__github-docs__search_generic_code({
  owner: "withastro",
  repo: "docs",
  query: "client:load directive"
})
// Returns: 77 matches with file paths and URLs

// 3. Use pagination for more results
mcp__github-docs__search_generic_code({
  owner: "reactjs",
  repo: "react.dev",
  query: "useState",
  page: 2
})
```

**Limitations**:
- `fetch_generic_url_content` cannot fetch files >64K tokens
- Semantic search requires documentation to be indexed
- Returns file paths, not actual content (use Read tool after discovery)

### Tailwind CSS Tool (`mcp__tailwind__*`)

**Purpose**: Access Tailwind CSS utilities, colors, and configuration without leaving the editor.

**Available Tools**:
- `get_tailwind_utilities(category?, property?, search?)` - Get utility classes
- `get_tailwind_colors(colorName?, includeShades?)` - Get color palette info
- `get_tailwind_config_guide(framework?, topic?)` - Get config guides for specific frameworks
- `search_tailwind_docs(query, category?, limit?)` - Search Tailwind documentation
- `install_tailwind(framework, packageManager?, includeTypescript?)` - Generate install commands
- `convert_css_to_tailwind(css, mode?)` - Convert CSS to Tailwind utilities
- `generate_color_palette(baseColor, name, shades?)` - Create custom color palettes
- `generate_component_template(componentType, style?, responsive?, darkMode?)` - Generate component templates

**When to Use**:
- Need quick reference to Tailwind utilities while styling
- Converting existing CSS to Tailwind classes
- Setting up Tailwind in a new framework
- Generating consistent color palettes
- Creating common UI component templates

**Best Practices**:
```typescript
// Search for specific utilities
mcp__tailwind__get_tailwind_utilities({ search: "flex gap" })

// Convert CSS to Tailwind
mcp__tailwind__convert_css_to_tailwind({
  css: "display: flex; gap: 1rem; padding: 2rem;",
  mode: "classes" // or "inline" or "component"
})

// Generate component templates
mcp__tailwind__generate_component_template({
  componentType: "button",
  style: "modern",
  responsive: true,
  darkMode: true
})

// Create color palette from brand color
mcp__tailwind__generate_color_palette({
  baseColor: "#4F46E5",
  name: "brand",
  shades: [50, 100, 200, 300, 400, 500, 600, 700, 800, 900, 950]
})
```

### Firecrawl Tool (`mcp__firecrawl__*`)

**Purpose**: Powerful web scraping and search with content extraction.

**Available Tools**:
- `firecrawl_scrape(url, formats?, maxAge?)` - Scrape single page (fastest, use `maxAge` for caching)
- `firecrawl_search(query, limit?, sources?, scrapeOptions?)` - Search web and extract content
- `firecrawl_map(url, limit?, search?)` - Discover all URLs on a website
- `firecrawl_crawl(url, limit?, maxDiscoveryDepth?)` - Crawl entire site (‚ö†Ô∏è can be very large)
- `firecrawl_extract(urls[], prompt?, schema?)` - Extract structured data using LLM
- `firecrawl_check_crawl_status(id)` - Check crawl job progress

**When to Use**:
- Research latest framework/API changes not in Claude's training data
- Scrape competitor features or design patterns
- Extract structured data from multiple pages
- Discover site structure before targeted scraping
- Need content with images, markdown, or HTML formats

**Best Practices**:
```typescript
// Fast single page scrape with caching
mcp__firecrawl__firecrawl_scrape({
  url: "https://example.com/docs/api",
  formats: ["markdown"],
  maxAge: 172800000 // 48 hours (500% faster)
})

// Web search with content extraction
mcp__firecrawl__firecrawl_search({
  query: "Vue 3 Composition API best practices 2025",
  limit: 5,
  sources: [{ type: "web" }],
  scrapeOptions: {
    formats: ["markdown"],
    onlyMainContent: true
  }
})

// Map site before scraping
mcp__firecrawl__firecrawl_map({
  url: "https://docs.example.com",
  search: "api-reference" // Optional filter
})

// Extract structured data
mcp__firecrawl__firecrawl_extract({
  urls: ["https://example.com/product1", "https://example.com/product2"],
  schema: {
    name: { type: "string" },
    price: { type: "number" },
    description: { type: "string" }
  }
})
```

**Limitations**:
- Crawl responses can exceed token limits (use `map` + targeted `scrape` instead)
- Respect robots.txt and rate limits
- Search results quality depends on query specificity

### Playwright Tool (`mcp__playwright__*`)

**Purpose**: Browser automation for testing, scraping dynamic content, and UI interactions.

**Available Tools**:
- `browser_navigate(url)` - Navigate to URL
- `browser_snapshot()` - Capture accessibility snapshot (better than screenshots for actions)
- `browser_take_screenshot(filename?, fullPage?, type?)` - Take visual screenshot
- `browser_click(element, ref, button?, modifiers?)` - Click elements
- `browser_type(element, ref, text, slowly?, submit?)` - Type into inputs
- `browser_fill_form(fields[])` - Fill multiple form fields at once
- `browser_select_option(element, ref, values[])` - Select dropdown options
- `browser_evaluate(function, element?, ref?)` - Execute JavaScript
- `browser_wait_for(text?, textGone?, time?)` - Wait for conditions
- `browser_tabs(action, index?)` - Manage browser tabs
- `browser_console_messages()` - Get console output
- `browser_network_requests()` - Inspect network traffic

**When to Use**:
- Test user workflows end-to-end
- Scrape JavaScript-rendered content
- Validate responsive designs across viewports
- Debug frontend issues in real browser environment
- Automate repetitive UI testing tasks
- Inspect network requests and console logs

**Best Practices**:
```typescript
// Navigate and capture state
mcp__playwright__browser_navigate({ url: "https://app.example.com" })
mcp__playwright__browser_snapshot() // For planning actions

// Fill and submit forms
mcp__playwright__browser_fill_form({
  fields: [
    { name: "email", type: "textbox", ref: "input#email", value: "test@example.com" },
    { name: "password", type: "textbox", ref: "input#password", value: "password123" },
    { name: "remember", type: "checkbox", ref: "input#remember", value: "true" }
  ]
})
mcp__playwright__browser_click({
  element: "submit button",
  ref: "button[type=submit]"
})

// Wait for results and capture
mcp__playwright__browser_wait_for({ text: "Welcome" })
mcp__playwright__browser_take_screenshot({
  filename: "logged-in.png",
  fullPage: true
})

// Debug with console/network
mcp__playwright__browser_console_messages()
mcp__playwright__browser_network_requests()

// Execute custom JavaScript
mcp__playwright__browser_evaluate({
  function: "() => document.querySelector('.user-name').textContent"
})

// Manage multiple tabs
mcp__playwright__browser_tabs({ action: "new" })
mcp__playwright__browser_tabs({ action: "select", index: 0 })
```

**Limitations**:
- Requires explicit user permission for interactions
- Screenshots are visual only (use `browser_snapshot` for actions)
- Long operations may timeout (use `wait_for` appropriately)
- Single browser instance per session

### Tool Selection Strategy

**For Documentation Research**:
1. Start with `mcp__github-docs__search_generic_code` to find relevant files
2. Use `Read` tool to examine specific files found
3. Use `mcp__firecrawl__firecrawl_search` for content not in GitHub repos

**For Web Research**:
1. Use `mcp__firecrawl__firecrawl_search` for quick searches with content
2. Use `mcp__firecrawl__firecrawl_scrape` for specific pages (with `maxAge` for speed)
3. Use `mcp__firecrawl__firecrawl_map` to discover before crawling
4. Use `mcp__playwright__browser_navigate` for JavaScript-heavy sites

**For UI Development**:
1. Use `mcp__tailwind__*` tools for styling utilities and references
2. Use `mcp__tailwind__convert_css_to_tailwind` when refactoring
3. Use `mcp__tailwind__generate_component_template` for consistent UI patterns
4. Use `mcp__playwright__*` tools to test final implementations

**For Testing**:
1. Use `mcp__playwright__browser_*` for E2E user flow testing
2. Use `browser_snapshot()` to plan test steps
3. Use `browser_console_messages()` and `browser_network_requests()` for debugging

# CLAUDE.md

This file provides guidance to Claude Code (claude.ai/code) when working with code in this repository.

## Project Overview

Socialaize is a comprehensive social media management platform that enables users to manage multiple social accounts, schedule posts, analyze performance, and leverage AI for content creation. The platform supports all major social networks including Facebook, Instagram, Twitter/X, LinkedIn, TikTok, YouTube, Pinterest, Mastodon, Threads, and Bluesky.

## Technology Stack

### Frontend
- **Astro 5.8** - Static site generator with SSR support via Cloudflare Workers
- **Vue 3** - Component framework with Composition API
- **TypeScript** - Primary development language
- **Tailwind CSS 4.1** - Styling framework
- **Nanostores** - State management
- **Cloudflare Pages** - Deployment platform

### Backend
- **Appwrite** - Backend-as-a-Service (database, auth, storage, functions)
- **Node.js 21** - Primary runtime for serverless functions
- **Python 3.11** - AI/ML services (FastAPI backend)
- **Bun** - Fast runtime for specific functions

### AI & Analytics
- **FastAPI** - Python API service for AI operations
- **LlamaIndex** - RAG and content processing
- **Qdrant** - Vector database
- **Redis** - Caching and chat history
- **OpenAI** - Content generation

## Common Development Commands

### Main Application
```bash
# Development
npm run dev              # Start local dev server
npm run start            # Alias for dev

# Building
npm run build            # Production build
npm run build:dev        # Development build with dev config
npm run build:full       # Build with type checking
npm run preview          # Preview production build
npm run preview:cf       # Preview with Cloudflare Workers

# Appwrite Setup
npm run set-appwrite-client  # Configure Appwrite CLI client
```

### Python AI API (in /api directory)
```bash
uv run dev              # Development server
uv run prod             # Production server
uv sync                 # Install dependencies
```

### Appwrite Functions (in each function directory)
```bash
npm install             # Install dependencies
npm run build           # TypeScript compilation
npm run format          # Code formatting (if available)
```

## Architecture Overview

### Serverless Functions Architecture
The platform uses **Appwrite Functions** for all backend logic. Each function is self-contained with consistent patterns:

**Function Categories:**
- **Social Media APIs** - Platform integrations (FacebookApi, InstagramApi, etc.)
- **Core Management** - Business logic (PostManager, WorkflowManager, SyncManager)
- **Utilities** - Support services (FileMetadataHandler, EmailHandler, etc.)
- **AI/ML Services** - Python-based processing (SentimentAnalyzer, VideoDownloader)

**Standard Function Structure:**
```
functions/[FunctionName]/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ src/
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ main.ts/js/py     # Entry point
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ handlers/         # Business logic
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ types/           # TypeScript definitions
‚îÇ   ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ utils/           # Utilities
‚îÇ   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ constants/       # Configuration
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ package.json         # Dependencies and scripts
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ tsconfig.json        # TypeScript config
```

### Database Schema Patterns
All database schemas are defined in TypeScript with comprehensive type safety:
- Located in `src/appwrite/` for frontend
- Individual schema files in each function's `types/` directory
- Extensive use of Zod for runtime validation

### Frontend Architecture
- **Pages**: Astro pages with SSR capability
- **Components**: Vue 3 components using Composition API
- **Stores**: Nanostores for reactive state management
- **Utilities**: Shared utilities in `src/utils/`

### Analytics System
Comprehensive analytics dashboard with:
- **Drag & Drop Interface** - Customizable widget layouts
- **15+ Chart Types** - Powered by ECharts
- **Real-time Data** - Dynamic updates and filtering
- **TypeScript Integration** - Full type safety

## Key Development Patterns

### Error Handling
- Consistent error handling across all functions
- Structured logging throughout the application
- Rate limiting for external API calls

### Authentication & Authorization
- JWT-based authentication via Appwrite
- OAuth integration for social platform connections
- Team-based permission system

### Type Safety
- End-to-end TypeScript usage
- Shared schemas between frontend and functions
- Zod validation for runtime type checking

### Event-Driven Architecture
- Functions triggered by database events
- Webhook handling for social platform updates
- Async processing for long-running tasks

## Working with Appwrite Functions

### Function Development
1. Each function has its own dependencies and build process
2. Use `npm run build` to compile TypeScript
3. Functions are deployed via Appwrite CLI
4. All functions use `node-appwrite` SDK for database operations

### Function Types by Runtime
- **Node.js 21**: Most API functions and core logic
- **Bun**: Performance-critical functions (FileMetadataHandler, utilities)
- **Python 3.11**: AI/ML functions (SentimentAnalyzer, VideoDownloader)

### Database Events
Some functions are triggered by database events (e.g., PostManager responds to post container changes). Check `appwrite.json` for event configurations.

## Testing and Deployment

### Local Development
- Frontend runs on `localhost:4321` with `npm run dev`
- Python API typically runs on `localhost:8000` with `uv run dev`
- Appwrite functions are deployed to cloud environment

### Build Process
- Use `npm run build:full` for production builds with type checking
- Each function builds independently with `npm run build`
- Python API uses `uv` for dependency management

### Cloudflare Integration
- Frontend deploys to Cloudflare Pages
- SSR handled by Cloudflare Workers
- Preview builds available with `npm run build:preview`

## Important Files and Directories

- `appwrite.json` - Defines all 25+ serverless functions and their configurations
- `src/appwrite/` - Complete TypeScript definitions for all database collections
- `functions/` - All serverless function implementations
- `api/` - Python FastAPI service for AI operations
- `src/components/analytics/` - Analytics dashboard components
- `AnalyticsReadme.md` - Comprehensive analytics system documentation

## Development Guidelines

### Code Style
- Use TypeScript throughout
- Follow existing patterns for error handling and logging
- Maintain consistent file structure across functions
- Use Zod schemas for validation

### Adding New Social Platforms
1. Create new API function in `functions/[Platform]Api/`
2. Implement OAuth flow in `OAuthManager`
3. Add database schemas for platform-specific data
4. Create post converter utilities

### Working with AI Features
- AI functionality handled by Python FastAPI service in `/api`
- Uses LlamaIndex for RAG and content processing
- Vector storage in Qdrant for embeddings
- Chat history stored in Redis

## Gemini Integration for Large File Analysis

This project has Gemini CLI MCP server configured for handling large file analysis that exceeds Claude's context window.

### Auto-Delegation Rules

**ALWAYS use Gemini (`mcp__gemini-cli__ask-gemini`) for:**
- Files > 500 lines - Automatically delegate to Gemini with @file syntax
- Multiple file analysis (3+ files) - Have Gemini analyze all files together
- Entire directory analysis - Use Gemini to scan and summarize patterns
- Type definition files (.d.ts) - Gemini handles large type files efficiently
- Generated files (dist/, build/) - Gemini's context handles large generated code
- Log files or data files - Gemini can process massive logs/data
- **Web searches during code analysis** - Gemini can search while analyzing files
- **Research + implementation combos** - Search for best practices then compare with code

### Usage Pattern
```typescript
// For single large file
mcp__gemini-cli__ask-gemini("@path/to/large-file.ts What patterns are used?")

// For multiple files
mcp__gemini-cli__ask-gemini("@file1.ts @file2.ts @file3.ts Compare these implementations")

// For directory analysis
mcp__gemini-cli__ask-gemini("@src/components/**/*.vue Analyze all Vue components")

// Web search for quick facts
mcp__gemini-cli__ask-gemini("Search for latest Vue 3.5 breaking changes 2025")

// Code analysis + web research combo
mcp__gemini-cli__ask-gemini("@src/auth/jwt.ts Search for JWT security best practices 2025 and compare with this implementation")

// Research while analyzing multiple files
mcp__gemini-cli__ask-gemini("@functions/PostManager/* Search for post scheduling patterns and analyze how this implementation compares")
```

### Workflow Strategy
1. **Gemini analyzes + researches** ‚Üí Reads large files, searches web for best practices, identifies patterns
2. **Claude implements** ‚Üí Generates code, fixes bugs, refactors based on Gemini's findings
3. **Best of both**: Gemini's 1M+ token context + web search + Claude's reasoning & code generation

### When to Use Gemini
- ‚úÖ Before refactoring large files - Get Gemini's analysis first
- ‚úÖ When user asks about file structure/patterns - Delegate to Gemini
- ‚úÖ For codebase-wide searches - Gemini can scan entire directories
- ‚úÖ When context window fills up - Offload reading to Gemini
- ‚úÖ **Quick web searches** - Gemini searches faster than Claude's WebSearch for facts
- ‚úÖ **Research + code analysis together** - Compare code against latest best practices
- ‚úÖ **Real-time API/framework updates** - Check latest features while analyzing code
- ‚ùå For code generation - Use Claude's strengths
- ‚ùå For small files (<500 lines) - Use Claude's Read tool
- ‚ùå For comprehensive research reports - Use Claude's `/web-search` command instead

## Package Management
- **Frontend**: PNPM (specified in package.json)
- **Python API**: UV (modern Python package manager)
- **Functions**: NPM (individual package.json files)

# ClaudeMcpTools Integration

This project uses ClaudeMcpTools with enhanced MCP tools for development.

## Quick Start Commands

### Smart File Operations
- `list_files(directory=".")` - List files with smart ignore patterns
- `find_files(pattern="*.py")` - Search files by pattern  
- `easy_replace(file_path, old_text, new_text)` - Fuzzy string replacement
- `take_screenshot()` - Cross-platform screenshots

### Project Analysis
- `analyze_project_structure(project_path=".")` - Generate .treesummary files
- `generate_project_summary(project_path=".")` - AI-optimized project overview
- `detect_dead_code(project_path=".")` - Find unused code

### Documentation Intelligence  
- `scrape_documentation(url="https://docs.example.com")` - Scrape and index docs
- `search_documentation(query="API usage")` - Semantic search with AI
- `link_docs_to_code(project_path=".")` - Connect docs to code

### Multi-Agent Workflows
- `spawn_agent(agent_type="implementer", repository_path=".")` - Create specialized agents
- `create_task(repository_path=".", task_type="feature")` - Coordinate development tasks
- `join_room(room_name="dev-team")` - Real-time agent communication

### Shared Memory & Error Logging
- `store_memory_entry(repository_path=".", agent_id, entry_type="insight", title, content)` - Store insights for other agents
- `query_shared_memory(repository_path=".", query_text="authentication")` - Search previous agent work
- `store_agent_insight(repository_path=".", agent_id, insight_type="pattern", category="architecture", title, description)` - Share discoveries
- `log_error(repository_path=".", error_type="runtime", error_category="mcp_tool", error_message)` - Enhanced error logging
- `get_error_patterns(repository_path=".")` - Learn from previous failures
- `get_recent_errors(repository_path=".")` - Debug current issues

## Agent Collaboration Features

### Cross-Agent Memory
Agents can store and share discoveries, tool results, and insights:
```
# Store a discovery for other agents
store_memory_entry(
    repository_path=".",
    agent_id="agent-123", 
    entry_type="discovery",
    title="Authentication Pattern Found",
    content="Project uses JWT with refresh tokens in src/auth/",
    tags=["authentication", "security", "jwt"]
)

# Query previous agent work
query_shared_memory(
    repository_path=".",
    query_text="authentication patterns",
    entry_types=["discovery", "insight"]
)
```

### Error Learning System
Comprehensive error tracking with pattern recognition:
```
# Log errors with full context
log_error(
    repository_path=".",
    error_type="runtime",
    error_category="file_operation", 
    error_message="Permission denied accessing config.json",
    context={"file_path": "./config.json", "operation": "read"},
    attempted_solution="Tried chmod 644"
)

# Learn from patterns
get_error_patterns(repository_path=".", min_frequency=2)
```

## Usage Patterns

**Quick Analysis**: "Please analyze_project_structure to understand this codebase"
**Multi-Agent Feature**: "Spawn agents to implement user auth with tests and docs"
**Documentation Setup**: "Scrape the React docs and make them searchable locally"
**Smart Search**: "Find all files that import the authentication module"
**Collaborative Development**: "Store your findings in shared memory for other agents to reference"
**Error Analysis**: "Check recent errors and their patterns to avoid repeating issues"

Data stored locally at `~/.claude/zmcptools/` with 85-90% token cost reduction via caching.
